abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts were only modest. Lessons learned are addressed as
            follows. First, lessons for project preparation indicate
            that although the project was not featured in the Country
            Assistance Strategy (needing additional funding allocation
            from the International Development Association (IDA) because
            of the civil conflict, it was nonetheless successfully
            implemented given its relief type lending, where assistance
            from Bank staff, provided strong inputs, even in the absence
            of a sector development strategy. However, a project such as
            this one, designed as a quick relief operation, should
            include sufficient activities for the physical outputs, and
            address capacity issues to ensure sustainability;
            additionally, arrangements for the road fund should have
            been made under the project, with assistance to be
            undertaken from the private sector. Second, as for project
            implementation, recommendations suggest that sound
            accounting, and financial management systems should have
            been included, to avoid irreconcilable difficulties of
            project accounts. Third, as per a post conflict assistance,
            it is paramount to count on political stability, or to be
            able to minimize claims due to force majeure, the absence of
            which delayed the resumption of some project activities,
            which are still unsettled.
